results.title: Looking for Alibrandi [DVD]
results.creator_credit: AFFC, Premium Movie Partnership, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Robyn Kershaw and Kate Woods
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by first time writer Melina Marchetta, “Looking for Alibrandi” is an affectionate look at three generations of strong willed Italian women, and the youngest member, Josie’s (Pia Miranda) attempt to break the family “curse”. 17 year old Josie lives with her single mother Christina (Greta Scacchi), is completing her HSC at an exclusive Sydney school on a scholarship, begrudgingly visiting her Nonna, defending the labels of “wog” and “bastard”, and longing after the lifestyle afforded to rich kids with both parents. When her father, Michael (Anthony La Paglia) enters their lives again, Josie confronts her mother and her Nonna about the rift between Christina and her father, and the animosity between mother and daughter to reveal secrets long since hidden. Josie must also make decisions about her future career and what her heart desires as she is torn between school captain John Barton (Matthew Newton) and public school boy Jacob (Kick Gurry). Between work, school, family and personal relationships, Josie discovers that life is filled with uncertainty and she is not the only one debilitated by the labels society ascribes. This was the first feature film effort for both director Woods and actor Miranda. Remarkably, the film was nominated and won several AFI awards, including best film, best supporting actress (Scacchi) and best performance by an actress in a leading role (Miranda).

results.title: Looking beyond: story of a film council
results.brief_description: A story from rural Canada, showing how 16 mm. documentary films have been applied to improvement of conditions in the community. Commences with the annual meeting of the film council - the voluntary organisation which fosters the use of films in the programs of local groups. Explains how the film council was formed following a diphtheria epidemic which the local doctor blamed on ignorance and inertia. Excerpts from the life of the community illustrate some of the many ways in which the use of films contributed to the welfare of the community and to the enlightenment of its citizens.

results.title: Looking at transport
results.brief_description: The design of London Transport’s trains and vehicles, buildings, equipment and furniture reveals a style which is characteristic of the whole undertaking, and which this film shows dates from 1916, when Frank Pick commissioned a new type face for use in London Transport’s public notices. Since then, and not least in its printing and posters, London Transport has sought to maintain a high standard of good looks throughout the field in which it operates.

results.title: Looking at the wild
results.brief_description: Harry Butler shows aspiring naturalists some of the simpler but fundamental techniques necessary to enjoy more fully a natural bush environment. Harry comments on the dress and basic equipment; demonstrates simple pit-traps and more complex fauna traps; and stresses the need for interest and enquiry in the natural bush environment.

results.title: Looking at sculpture
results.brief_description: Made to encourage people to visit museums and to show how to mkae the best use of such visits. The film studies critically three pieces of sculpture in the Victoria and Albert Museum; a Madonna and child carved in whalebone by an early Anglo-Saxon, carved in wood by Veit Stoss and in terra-cotta by Rosellino. The film comments on the general characteristics of art in the Romanesque, Gothic and early Renaissance pieces respectively. Commentary by Michael Redgrave.

results.title: Looking at Puffing Billy
results.brief_description: An enthusiasts video production about the Puffing Billy railway beginning with a brief history of the line, its relatively recent retoration, and the work of the Puffing Bily Preservation Society. We are taken on a detailed trip along the line from Belgrave to Emerald Lake.

results.title: Looking at poems
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Open University and Nuala O'Faolain
results.brief_description: Argues that poems demand a special attention and that there is no correct single response to a poem. To emphasise this, three people are shown responding spontaneously after reading the following short lyric poems: “So we’ll go no more a-roving” (Byron), “An Arundel tomb: stanza five” (Larkin), “Love” (Herbert), and “After great pain” (Dickinson). Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Looking at plants
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Jim Harris and John Bird
results.brief_description: Filmed in the Sherbrooke Forest Park, Australflora Nursery, Victoria, and shows glimpses of the plant and insect life which abound there. No narration, music only.

results.title: Looking at paperwork
results.creator_credit: Rank Organisation Film Productions, British Productivity Council and Robert Parker
results.brief_description: Presents an Organisation and Methods approach to administrative practice, showing typical ways of improving its efficiency. Two questions are asked - “How is the work being done?” and “Is the work being done really necessary?”.
